summary: Optimizing macOS CI Job Performance in GitHub Actions

message.content: I want to try a new way of triaging issues. Can you please go through github issues which do not have aen assignee and find me which ones to assign to Emily please?

content.text: I'll help you triage unassigned GitHub issues to find ones suitable for Emily. Let me fetch the current unassigned issues from the nrwl/nx repository.

input.command: gh issue list --repo nrwl/nx --assignee="" --state open --limit 50 --json number,title,labels,author,createdAt --jq '.[] | {number, title, labels: [.labels[].name], author: .author.login, created: .createdAt}'
input.description: Fetch unassigned open issues from nrwl/nx repo

content.text: Let me fix the jq command:

input.command: gh issue list --repo nrwl/nx --assignee="" --state open --limit 50 --json number,title,labels,author,createdAt
input.description: Fetch unassigned open issues from nrwl/nx repo with JSON output

content.content:
title:	@nx/webpack/app-plugin doesn't handle multiple entry point with "exports"
state:	OPEN
author:	Wykks
labels:	type: bug
comments:	0
assignees:	
projects:	
milestone:	
number:	31419
--
### Current Behavior

The code here:

https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/f02cc49b067643818f38e97a28e7e18b9af40b98/packages/rspack/src/plugins/utils/get-non-buildable-libs.ts#L14-L45

Doesn't handle the case when you want to create a library without barrel file. It incorrectly assume that there's only one entry point, with an implicit index.ts file.

If I manually add my lib like this (by patching the file apply-base-config.js):

```
[...]
nonBuildableWorkspaceLibs.push('@monorepo/mylib/stuff');
externals.push(
      nodeExternals({ modulesDir, allowlist: nonBuildableWorkspaceLibs }), 
);
```

(ref: https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/f02cc49b067643818f38e97a28e7e18b9af40b98/packages/webpack/src/plugins/nx-webpack-plugin/lib/apply-base-config.ts#L358-L368)

The build correctly include "@monorepo/mylib/stuff" in the final bundle.

### Expected Behavior

@nx/webpack/app-plugin should be able to handle the "exports" field correctly.
Everything work fine if you remove the barrel file in a modern ts monorepo; except the build which seems to be the last final piece to finally avoid barrel file for libs.

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

In a workspace nodejs monorepo, create a library and remove the barrel file, and use "exports" to expose all files in src, like this: 

```
{
  "name": "@monorepo/mylib",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "private": true,
  "exports": {
    "./*": "./src/*.ts"
  }
}
```


### Nx Report

```shell

npm            : 10.9.2
```

content.content:
title:	Tutorial: Advanced Angular Micro Frontends with Dynamic Module Federation - Error in command
state:	OPEN
author:	devAnky
labels:	priority: low, scope: angular, type: docs
comments:	2
assignees:	Coly010
projects:	
milestone:	
number:	31410
--
In the part [Adding functionality](https://nx.dev/recipes/angular/dynamic-module-federation-with-angular#adding-functionality) it states 

> We need an Angular Service that we will use to hold state:

and to run the command
`nx g @nx/angular:service libs/shared/data-access-user/src/lib/user`
This command prompts the error:
`Required property 'project' is missing`

Copilot said, the command just needs an additional argument `--project`.
So I guess the correct command would be:
`nx g @nx/angular:service libs/shared/data-access-user/src/lib/user --project=data-access-user`

I think the tutorial should be corrected.

content.content:
title:	In @nx/eslint, --fix should respect --quiet
state:	OPEN
author:	bkp-ttd
labels:	priority: medium, scope: linter, type: bug
comments:	0
assignees:	leosvelperez
projects:	
milestone:	
number:	31401
--
### Current Behavior

When using `eslint` directly, `eslint --fix --quiet` will only fix issues that aren't silenced by `--quiet`. However `nx run lint --quiet --fix` has the opposite behavior - it will attempt to autofix all lint issues, even ones that would normally be ignored by `--quiet`.

In other words, `nx run lint --quiet --fix` behaves the same as `nx run lint --fix`.

I think it's an easy fix - pull request incoming...

### Expected Behavior

`nx run lint --quiet --fix` should only fix issues that aren't silenced by `--quiet`

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Write some code that produces fixable lint warnings (not errors)
2. Verify that those warnings are silenced by `--quiet` and appear without `--quiet`
3. Run `nx run lint --quiet --fix` and observe that the warnings are fixed
